Well, as someone who already well verse into flight combat sims like IL-2 Great Battle, this is a decent, albiet lightweight flight combat game. As a follower of Atypical Game since the first Sky Gambler, it has a place in my heart as my office break game, and relieve my stress during the stressful time of my early work days.

On PC, it is designed to be play on low spec PC, anything beyond 2016 graphical PC game would be a complete overkill. But it ran really really smoothly on my 2013 Asus A53S series laptop with the Nvdia GT540 graphics(this machine is ancient and really really obseleted by 2020 standards by light years) card while keeping the graphic clean, clear and pretty. I enjoyed it for being a pretty fun game with a well done touch and keyboard configuration despite being clearly a mobile port. The only downside of this game is that it can be really grindy, but at least it being fun and short.

I hope in the future Atypical Games will made crossave a feature between Google Play and Steam so I can play seamless transitions between mobile and PC. The Sky Gambler series has a special place in my heart.

author: {'steamid': '76561199205201461', 'num_games_owned': 22, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 870, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1671472497}
review:
Overall, I enjoyed a lot of things about game, but there was also a fair number of things I disliked so let me be more specific about all the good and the bad in this game.

First off, this game is a unrealistic arcade flight game, not a realistic flight simulator. Personally, this didn't bother me as I was looking for a more arcadic game but people who don't like this type of game should pass on this one.

As a port of a mobile game the graphics are... meh. The Aircraft models themselves look alright but the environments look ugly but I'm not much of a graphics day myself so that didn't matter much to me. The game also has some small hitbox issues too. When I was playing the entire wing of my aircraft would clip into the ground before actually crashing.

The audio is probably the weakest aspect in my opinion. outside of the main menu the only place music plays is in the campaign, this means that mostly the only thing you hear outside of the Campaign is machine gun sounds and propeller noises and both of which sound very low quality. And the music in the campaign isn't that good either and it all has a sloppy seam between the loop in the tracks.

The gameplay is simple arcadic fun with a few extra interesting features to keep it from being too terribly boring but nothing too complicated such as linking you're primary and secondary weapons, blowing out you're engines from boosting for too long, having a system failure in your plane from taking too much damage, and having your pilot pass out from too much G-force. The map selection is pretty underwhelming. There's only five maps and they all feel too similar. The planes all feel a little too the same outside of slightly different Armor, maneuverability and weapons. The controls are a little sloppy and really show it's mobile game roots. You'll need to click on the screen at times similar to how you'd tap on a phone screen.

The amount of content is the best part in my opinion. As a fan of World War II plane it has almost every plane that I personally care about with the Flying Fortress and the Mitchell being being the only plane that I like that are absent. In fact, heavy bomber like those are absent all together so be prepared for that if you like those sort of aircraft. What surprised me was the presence of a progression system. You play games, to level up by earning XP from playing games which will unlock new planes, all of which have three different variants of and can have their paint jobs recolored. And the best part about the progression is that you earn EX even when you play Single-player which you may be forced to do given it's small playerbase. You can play multiplayer games with bots so you can experience something similar to multiplayer even with they are pretty dumb. There are five multiplayer modes Free-for-All, Team Deathmatch, Capture the Flag and Last Man Standing are all pretty self explanatory and the final mode, Base Attack where you have to destroy enemy bases to score while defending your own. In the campaign, you fly in both the Battle of Britain and across the pacific front. It isn't the best campaign but it does provide some simple fly around and shoot them up fun if you're looking for that. And finally there's Survival mode and Dogfight mode which both involve you fighting alone against NPC enemies.

All in all, I recommend this to anyone who is looking for simple, shoot 'em up arcadic fun like I was. it's not for anyone looking for a more complicated flight simulator. I'd probably give it a 7/10.

review:
This is perfect for my 8 year old son. We both love WWII planes, and this game is a nice combination of nicely modelled aircraft, smooth flying and exciting dog-fighting action with a really easy to use/understand control scheme. It streams nicely to the small micro PC in his bedroom, runs very solidly and has very modest system requirements. There are some nice in-game finishing touches, that come as something as a surprise, and the selection of planes is excellent, with all the favourites (Spitfire, Mustang, Bf109 etc.) and a few surprises (like the Horton 'flying wing' jet). 

There are so few games like this that are designed to appeal to people in this age range that aren't.. well.. a bit boring. This is the game I'd have loved when I was a kid, so I sincerely hope the developers make more games like this and don't get persuaded by the 'realism or death' crowd, or the 'it's not indie if it's not pixel art' gang. In short, this has provided plenty of fun and was money well spent.

review:
Before I write this review, I’ll have to set things straight that this game is an arcade shooter not a combat flight sim. Thus I am going to review this as such despite the fact that I am a hardcore flight sim gamer.

Nevertheless, for all this game is worth there are a few things that I like, but there are more that I don’t

What I like:

1. The game has the potential to be fun given the fast pace nature of its game play.
2. There is a wide variety of planes to choose from albeit you won’t be able to feel how the plane would actually handle since this is an arcade shooter not a sim.
3. For nostalgia purposes, this game is reminiscent of those Lucas Arts games titled, Secret Weapons over Normandy that has a good story
4. The game runs on Linux native.

What I don’t like:

1. Although the game has potential, it does not fully support Logitech’s Extreme 3D Pro – a fairly common joystick. Some of the buttons simply do not work.
2. The should really be aimed at children 7 years old and younger especially those who show interest with aviation.

Would I recommend this? Maybe... But then again, I am no child anymore.

review:
SG SR is a nice game, with basic mechanics and the fun of arcade games. 

For a strange case I've played about all the arcade games that have war airplanes, and I must say this is not the best and not the worst.

After this experience I have to admin that the best game about arcade dogfights is, in my opinion, Air Conflict pacific carriers, but for some reasons it has a couple of bugs.

If you want instead a very good graphic the choice fall on Flying Tigers: Shadows Over China, but there is no trama behind and the story is a bit flat..

Then again a very full immersion game with naval, submarine and aerial combat is Battlestations pacific, but it's not so arcade.

At last, if you want to play this title, it's ok, but expect a light game and some hours of fun. Nothing more. 

In general the graphics begun to be a bit old, even if watched from the sky, and the gameplay stay very similar during all the campaigns and using all the airplanes. Nice the fact that you have to take off or return home, but as I said, I prefer Air Conflict that also does those kind of things.

Take it on budget in any case.

Lord Hol Napult's exp: 6+/10

review:
想通关很简单，收集一些成就，解锁战机的条件就需要自己摸索了。

review:
This is NOT "The Ultimate WWII Air Combat game" as the store page claims nor does it seem to have any real coop options.

It IS a very simple arcade shooter with a World War 2 aircraft theme. Definitely not a sim nor indeed anywhere nearly as realistic as many arcady games like Combat Wings Battle of Britain or Dogfight 1942. Still of you want a more modern version of a game like 1942 with a 3d flight model, this might be what you are looking for.

(War Thunder of course, has far more realistic air combat though that game is live service trash with all the usual MMO BS so this game is still better IMHO.)

One problem with the store page is that the "coop" tag appears to be inaccurate. The only online option appears to be PVP (in other words cheaters and/or no-lifers.)

6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198064388679', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 205, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 360, 'last_played': 1704365102}
review:
[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Sea looks excellent at Very High detail
[*]Planes look real, shiny while having a worn out paint effect
[*]Sound effects are good; guns, explosions, engine roar
[*]Detailed cockpit view with control stick animation
[*]You can look around both from inside and outside the plane
[*]Landing is required in certain campaign missions; obviously i dig landing.
[*]3 difficulty levels: Rookie, Pilot and Ace
[*]3 control schemes: keyboard, joystick and mouse
[*]There's boost power similar in function to afterburners
[*]Squadron commands: Attack, Defend, Reform
[*][b][i]Friendly AI smart enough to do their jobs.This is quite rare in games.[/i][/b]
[*]No DLC needed
[*]Plenty of planes but some needed to be unlocked
[*]Free flight mode where you can just explore without getting shot at
[*]3 campaigns; British vs Germans, US vs Germans and US vs Japan
[*]There are some cutscenes but there is no wow factor.
[*]There is a total of 6+6+5 missions in all 3 campaigns; 17 is a nice prime number
[*]There are more modes than just Campaigns.
[*]You're usually outnumbered but it never feels unfair.
[/list]

Cons
[list]
[*]No manual control for landing gear. It's automatically deployed almost instantly on touchdown.
[*]Music is repetitive
[*]Auto-aim sometimes makes it too easy. Not that i'm complaining; it's just so hard to find a con.
[*]On the 4th mission of the British campaign you suddenly fly for the Germans. I think the developer forgot which side he was fighting for.
[*]There is no voice acting so it's kinda weird with no radio chatter.
[/list]


[b]Why it's arcade[/b]
It's quite close to a simulation but it's arcade because:
[list]
[*]Weapons have unlimited reloads although cooldown is needed between reloads
[*]If you die, you respawn at the previous checkpoint with 100% health. Again not that i'm complaining.
[/list]

Overall it's very fun and easy to get into. No complicated controls nor too many keys to remember.

Recommended with an estimated rating of [b]7/10[/b]. Could be higher if the music wasn't repetitive and there is radio chatter to increase immersion.

review:
Sky Gamblers Storm Raiders is a simple, arcade WW2 flight simulator that's enjoyable for a couple of hours.
The game covers a number of historical WW2 battles including Pearl Harbour, the battle for England etc. and the campaign brings you many of the typical locations you expect from a WW2 game, like France, Britain, Germany and the Pacific.

As an Android port, graphics are not as polished as some AAA titles but the game is still fun to play.

Pros:
- classic dogfights
- easy controls 
- supports joystick, keyboard and mouse 
- configurable controls
- water looks fantastic
- three different outside perspectives and cockpit view
- great weather effects
- option to repair your plane during fights by landing on runways (risky)
- smooth gameplay, no bugs, no crashes
- different weapons
- huge list of WW2 air-planes, which can be unlocked throughout the course of the game
- nice campaign (although a little too simple)
- volumetric clouds
- smooth multiplayer access, just log in and join a game any time
- active multiplayer, I was always able to find mp games (although not many)
- different multiplayer game modes

Cons:
- planes all feel very similar
- repetitive gameplay (but that's in the nature of dogfights)
- poor textures
- aircraft's do not exceed their respective maximum speed, even not when nose-diving

review: Sky Gamblers: Storm Raiders gets a definite 4/5 from me with only a couple of minor faults to complain of. In general though I have found the game entertaining and action packed with three Campaign categories which can be played at one of three levels: Rookie/Pilot or Ace. The variety of aircraft is good although all seem to share the same Messerschmitt Bf-109 cockpit and once unlocked via playing the campaigns they can be used online where the multiplayer appears to be far from dead. Features a free flight and a number of combat situation modes putting you up against AI aircraft which are marked clearly with target indicators when playing at easy levels. The only problems to report are that at times the AI aircraft and multiplayer aircraft do not manoeuver smoothly and that as you manoeuver your aircraft particularly at high speed the blackout effect kicks in annoyingly and that this cannot be disabled. I just found this frustrating during dogfight and survival missions as it blacks out all target indications as well as the screen. You literally cannot see a thing even when playing at easy levels and this could serve as an impediment to learning the game / learning the different types of aircraft and what they are capable of. Definitely worth the GBP £4.99 spent on it though.

review:
Hat mich in und mit  seiner funktionalen Simplizität angenehm überrascht. Es erinnert (auch ?) mich an frühe 'ActionFlugSimulatoren (light)' a la 'Red Baron' und man sieht ihm die Portierung von den 'Mobiles' auf den PC kaum an.

Eine Menge 'Content', sowohl im Einzel-. als auch Mehrspielermodus und ein durchaus kurzweiliges und motivierendes Freischalt- und Belohnungssystem. Möglichkeiten zur Individualisierung der Flugzeuge (wenn auch nicht ausufernd) runden das Ganze ab.

Alles in allem ein ziemlich unterhaltsamer Casual-Pausenfüller, immer gut für 'mal ein Viertelstündchen ballern' und Motoren röhren hören.

Sicher nicht das beste Spiel aller Zeiten, aber von 'Preis/Leistung' her eine angenehme Überraschung, sofern man mit dem Genre etwas anfangen kann.

review:
My eyes might be bad, but this game is still fun. When I was in school, one of my favorite games for the PS2 was Secret Weapons over Normandy. This game feels similar with a bit more contol, which is a good thing. There are lots of planes to unlock, ranging from early WWII fighters to jets that came in toward the end of the war. Different campaigns have you flying planes from both Allied and Axis sides. Combat is fast and fun. The music is pretty decent. 

If you're a person who needs every single aspect of flight rendered in perfect scientific detail, this game might not be for you, but if you're like me and you love WWII planes, this game is a great investment for only 10 USD. If you get it when it's on sale, even better!

Cons to be aware of: 
No voice acting. All mission prompts are via text on screen. My vision sucks so I missed some. 
Several planes, but it feels like more could have been added. 99 cent DLCs with 5-8 planes would be nice.
Music can get a bit repetitive, but you don't notice if you're fighting.
I can't figure out how to lower landing gear.

author: {'steamid': '76561198190317386', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 292, 'last_played': 1456321535}
review:
このゲームは人によってかなり評価が分かれると思う。自分は精密な乗り物操作ゲームが苦手だが、かと言って乗り物操作ゲームが嫌いなわけではないのでこのゲームのように簡易的な操作でできる物はちょっとした息抜きにもなって良いと思った。
これをお勧めしない方々は恐らく出てくる戦闘機や武器の個性が出てないことに不満があるのだろうと思う。(あと簡易操作や大雑把なオブジェクトグラフィック)つまり戦闘機や機関銃はどれも同じようなもので飛ばして撃つだけであるということ。
戦闘機や武器に全く詳しくない自分にとってはちょうどいいゲームだった。
要するに、一応お勧めはするが、本格的な大戦中の戦闘機シミュレーションゲームをしたい方にとってはくそゲーと思うだろうし、簡易的に遊びたい人にはまあまあなセールの時にでも安いので買っとこうかなくらいのゲームであると思う。
ちなみにマルチは人がほとんどいないのだが実績解除項目が割とあるので、自分しか持ってない場合は実績のコンプが大変だろう。

review:
I was in search of an arcade-style dogfighting game that didn't require reading a huge flight manual first.  Nothing against those games, but sometimes I just don't have the time to devote to them.

Sky Gamblers turned out to be the game I was looking for.  It's easy to pick up and play, has a good variety of planes and combat scenarios, and it also supports joysticks.  After a short tutorial that teaches you the basics, you're off!

The graphics aren't going to push a 980ti to it's limits, but the game still looks good.  Overall it's definitely worth playing if realistic flight mechanics aren't that important to you, but having fun is.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998585368', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 163, 'last_played': 1449261253}
review:
Vornweg:
Macht das Spiel spaß?
Antwort:
JA!

Ist es ein Tolles Spiel?
Antwort:
NEIN!

Kurz und knackig;
Das wir es hier nicht mit einem Flugsimulator zu tun haben sollte jedem klar sein, der sich auch nur ganz kurz mal mit der Beschreibung auseinandersetzt. Realitische Flugphysik, Realistisches Motorenhandling und/oder auch nur halbwegs glaubwürdige Waffen/Schadensphysik können wir also ganz getrost aus dem Fenster schmeissen. Das hier ist ein Arcade-Shooter reinsten Wassers. Ein Joystick verbessert das handling zwar etwas, aber insgesammt sind sowohl das Handling der Maschienen wie auch das Treffermodel sehr zitterig, präzise Manöver ein Ding der Unmöglichkeit und überhaupt das ganze Gameplay mehr auf "Deutschiessen" gebürstet (Ist mein Fadenkreuz ungefähr in der gleichen richtung wie mein Gegner? Wenn ja: Feuer Frei!) Die Steuerrung per Stick ist minimal exakter als die per Maus oder Tastatur, aber wenn man keinen Joystick sein eigen nennt lohnt es auch nicht, extra für dieses Spiel einen Anzuschaffen; so nen riesen vorteil holt man nicht damit raus. Das ginge zwar noch wesentlich besser, aber im großen und ganzen ist die sache Ziemlich Solide und macht Laune. Im Multiplayer war ich zwar bis jetzt noch nicht unterwegs, aber das Scheint einer der großen Pluspunkte für das Spiel zu sein. Ich kann mir sehr gut vorstellen, dass das Geballer mit ein paar Freunden Tierisch spaß macht.

Womit wir uns den Negativen Aspekten des Spieles Widmen: Der Singleplayer. Die Kampagnen, einzelmissionen und KI-Bot-Fights sind zwar... naja, "OK", aber auch nicht so wirklich das gelbe vom Ei. Klar, Arcade-Shooter, also erwarte ich überhaupt nicht, das ich hier in irgendeiner weise mit Realismus belästigt werde, aber wenn der Dev mir mitten in der Mission nach tadellosem Flug plötzlich auf einmal 65% meiner Trefferpunkte abstreicht, 2 Feindliche Jagdmaschienen ans seitenruder Klebt und mir Motoraussetzer in die zuvor eigentlich Makellos gepflegte und Trefferfreie ME-626 einbaut und mir erzählt, das ich nur noch genau 60 sekunden Zeit habe um zu landen, weil mir sonst der Sprit ausgeht und ich nicht mal mehr im Gleitflug die 500m zur Landebahn zurücklegen kann (Da das Flugzeug ohne Spritt nur eine richtung kennt: Abwärts... Arcade-Physik FTW!) , dann schlagen bei mir Bullshit- und Frustrationszeiger aus, und zwar bis zum Anschlag. Und CUTSCENES! ... Oh mein Gott, die CUTSCENES... Sie unterbrechen das Spiel, einfach so, Mittendrin. Die Welt hält für 2 Sekunden die Luft an, man bekommt einen fetzen "storry" für die Mission vorgesetzt (Why? Ist "flieg rum und Knall alles ab, was nicht als Freund markiert ist!" nicht ausreichend?) und wird komplett aus seinem "Jagdtrieb" gerissen... nur um nach ende der Szene ohne vorwarnung genau da weiter zu machen, wo man vorher rausgerupft wurde... Auch wenn man grade noch im Sturzflug unterwegs war und versuchte, NICHT zum Pfankuchen am Erdboden zu werden. Ich weis nicht wie es der Jüngeren Generation geht, aber wenn ich den Joystick in Nullstellung bringe, um mir die Cutscene anzusehen, dann brauch ich länger als 0.01 Sekunden, um wieder auf "OMFG! HOCHZIEHEN! HOCHZIEHEN!!!" umzuschalten. Derartig grobe schnitzer müssen einfach nicht sein und können nur mit "Grottenschlechter oder untallentierter Leveldesigner" oder "Nackte, ungeschönte Faulheit" erklärt werden.

Fazit:
Für's multiplayer möglicherweise ziemlich Spaßig, Der Single-Player hat seine Schwächen (MISSIONSDESING!!!), die Grafik ist "Okäy-isch", die Steuerrung Hackelig, aber ausreichend. Insgesammt 2,5/5 Punkten. Für unter 5€ kann man sich eigentlich nicht beschweren, die ist das Spiel auf jeden fall wert.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116892501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 26045, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24274, 'last_played': 1696106704}
review:
Novedades: en la actualidad sólo funciona en linux forzando la compatibilidad con proton.
Sin ningún problema en Debian (cosa de agradecer). Es una combinación bastante buena entre arcade y simulación aérea, y no hay sorpresas, si alguien está buscando un simulador de verdad le recomiendo Flightgear [url]http://www.flightgear.org[/url], porque para hacerlo jugable es inevitable sacrificar casi todo el realismo.
Aunque hablen bien del modo multijugador, tiene modos para jugar en solitario que nos harán sudar... y también ganar la experiencia necesaria para desbloquear los aviones que nos interesen. Luego se trata de probar y quedarnos con aquel que nos dé mejor resultado.

Después de unas cuantes horas más (unas cien o así :) ) puedo añadir otros detalles:

Si queremos disfrutar del modo multijugador en primer lugar necesitaremos suerte, porque los servidores siempre suelen estar bastante saturados. Y segundo, y muy importante, deshabilitar el disparo fácil y practicar mucho para dominar la balística de los proyectiles (el puntero que tenemos es tan sólo aproximado).

Cada modelo tiene sus características particulares, de resitencia, potencia, rapidez y maniobrabilidad. Dos modelos potentes que están disponibles desde el principio son el Macchi y el Me 209, pero eso no quita que se experimente con los demás, puede que otros se adapten mejor a nuestro modo de volar.

Comparado con el modo arcade de War Thunder tiene una simulación de vuelo mucho menos realista, pero eso te da la oportunidad de hacer toda clase de piruetas imposibles y jugar con múltiples tácticas de evasión. En ese aspecto es mucho más divertido, mientras se tenga cuidado de no pasarse con la velocidad en los giros (de ahí que personalmente prefiera aviones "lentos" con buena maniobrabilidad, para no quedarme ciego a las primeras de cambio por el exceso de g's). author: {'steamid': '76561198188787550', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 953, 'last_played': 1431812917}
review:
To start with this is an arcade game and not a simulator, it was ported from phone to pc I think and they did quite a good job of it.  I personally play it with a joystick and I have to say for a phone port this game has better joystick response than War Thunder when last i played that game.  I had no trouble mapping buttons or with responsiveness in Storm Raiders compared to the buggy and mouse bias War Thunder which is a flight simulation game.  That aside I really have been enjoying this game.

Pros:
-Very easy to fly, it's just throttle up and you're off, this is an arcade game after all.
-3 Difficulty settings.
-Simple 3 modes wingman support: Attack / Defend / Formation
-Multiple control types supported, works great with a flight stick. (I use the Logitech Extreme 3D Pro)
-Good graphics, effects, & atmosphere music with the exception of one of the campaign missions.
-Larger scale air battles with large maps, you'll get into some decent furballs here.
-Three short campaigns filled with fun as well as several solo game modes that mimic the multiplayer games. 
-Active multiplayer online matches. (Deathmatch, Capture the Flag, & Destroy the Base.)
-Unlimited bullets with a heat mechanic, recharged rockets/bombs/torpedos mechanic. (Also a con for those who want realism.)
-Toggle Aim Assist, personally I found it easier with this disabled as I could kill enemies from outside the lead que range.
-New aircraft are earned by completing the campaigns and leveling up, you don't have to purchase them like the phone version.

Cons:
-There's only one internal cockpit model used in every plane, very sad. :(
-The campaigns are pretty short, about 5-6 missions long each it wont take long to finish them. (Also a pro for casuals.)
-For those that like realism, there's unlimited ammo & a radar system. (Again, it's an arcade game.)
-The physics are not the greatest but only really is bothersome when landing, if you cut your engine by boosting too much, or running out of fuel via campaign event. (There is no actual fuel consumption.) My first landing in this game dropped me dead from 2 meters up for a successful three point landing vtol style.  If you want a more realistic landing don't try to coast, go in low at 50% and grind the ground, wheels deploy automatically and then drop the throttle back. When you run out of fuel or kill your engine (temp only) you quite literally will start to drop straight down shortly after, there is no gliding in this game.

Really there isn't a whole lot about this game that bothers me, I really like flight games like the Ace Combat series up to game 5. (Assault Horizon was just a disappointment.)  While this game isn't an Ace Combat with an amazing story I found the gameplay engaging and fun.  At $9.99 I feel the game is well worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041603555', 'num_games_owned': 1621, 'num_reviews': 454, 'playtime_forever': 720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1427867568}
review:
Sky Gamblers: Storm Raiders is the third game in the Sky Gambler series, previously released as mobile games. As a result, this is turn-and-burn only, but for a WW2 turn and turn, it's surprisingly fun and decently balanced with some interesting complexities should you wish to delve into such. 

For a mobile port, this game is actually quite good. Terrain and flying area is nice and big, objects are not oddly scaled (things are tiny in a distance). Details are not PC standard, but quite workable. Enemy planes break apart when you kill them, with a wing falling off, then the whole things spins and twists like a falling leaf. And so on. Ground targets can hide among trees but that's why you have rockets and bombs. Or for naval targets, you have torpedoes and bombs. 

The engine can be "boosted" for a short period of high speed, but engine will overheat after X seconds, and may shut down altogether (but it will restart once you cooled off). Guns will also overheat and prone to jamming should you held down the trigger for too long. The temp gauge on either weren't too obvious though. 

There's quite a bit of decent single player content (2-3 campaigns, plus survival mode and dogfight mode) as well as full set of mulitplayer games including Capture the Flag, Free for All, and so on. There's also three difficulty levels so rookies can feel free to dive right in. 

Don't expect too much realism, as you have P-40 Warhawks fighting the Luftwaffe, or Hurricane carrying torpedoes, and so on. A fighter here do often carry bombs. And many of the scenarios have you attempting to race to the airfield before your fuel runs out on a timer, not on actual fuel consumption. On the other hand, they can be quite exciting, and these missions do have checkpoints so if you fail, you aren't forced to start from the beginning. 

Controls are easy enough, though the gamepad support should be better, as there needs to be some custom mapping. For games that supports such, I do "RC controls" (i.e. stick one controls elevator and roll, while stick two controls throttle and rudder) and this game was able to do such, but it wasn't the default. 

On some game types you can customize your plane, both paint job and the primary/secondary weapons, and choices are plenty, some are good for ground work, some are good for air attacks. 

With four classes of planes (fighter, bomber, jet, and legend), there are plenty of choices and lots of customization options. Legend class contains very iconic fighters as well as some prototypes that never made it into service but were very good planes. 

The interface is a little weird as often you have to rely on dragging to show more panels as there are no obvious signs there are more choices below; legacy of coming from a touch interface. 

All in all, SGSR is a pretty good game, for the turn-and-burn crowd. Don't expect "realism", flight model, and so on.

Now some bad points...
Firstly i noticed when you play in free flight the maps seems to be always at night which i dislike as you have to strain your eyes to see what is in front of you and this is bad programming would of been nice if you had a feature in the settings to choose night or day.

Also i notice when you unlock planes sometimes you unlock a plane you already have unlocked would of been better if you unlocked a improved version of the same plane such as better defence better guns and better roof limit and so on.

Wish there was a feature for a MAP to open up and see everything and where you are located and your objectives and the enemy.

My Suggestions....
Would of been nice if there was also a Medal feature for outstanding bravery and achievements in line with the plane you are flying at the time...Example if flying ME109 you would get geman medals if flying a spitfire British medals and so on

Also would of been nice to get money for destroying planes/ships/buildings and completing missions to buy upgrades for your planes.

Also to interact with your wingmen to promote them and improve their planes and award them medals too.

So i hope there will be changes to this game and improvements with patches but as it stands i can only give this game 7.5/10 which is about average score

review:
Sky Gamblers: Storm Raiders
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

First of all, I must say that I am not a fan of flight simulation at all. And there is only one reason for it, too hard to learn and play. 

Saying this, I was quiet intrigued with this game just because it looks fun. Let me tell you I was spot on. You do not have to remember how to start an engine and all the rest. All you have to do is to push up the throttle and you get to the fight within a minute and shoot planes. “RIGHT NOW AT 3 O’CLOCK!”

All fighter planes from the era are well represented in this game. Graphically, this game could have been better but you can’t have everything. To be honest they are decent.

For the controls side of it, I think using the mouse and keyboard is about as weird as it sounds. It will take you a little time to master both setups anyway.

You can play as a single player and have 3 campaigns at your disposal (Pacific, Africa and Battle of Britain). You also have a survival, capture the flag, dogfight, team deathmatch and defend the base which can be played against the AI. Multiplayer mode is also available.

Positives:
~~~~~~~~ 
-	Challenging and really fun to play
-	Plenty of modes including multiplayer
-	Runs smoothly
-	Stack of achievements
-	Trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~ 
-	Controls slightly sluggish

Overall, this game is worth $9.99 and I really enjoyed it! 

8/10

review: I have been a huge fan of Revo Games and the Sky Gamblers series for a little over a year now. author: {'steamid': '76561198038338214', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 458, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 457, 'last_played': 1422668580}
review:
If you played the mobile version and always wished to play it on your laptop/desktop/bigger screen, with better view of the action, then the time has come for your dreams to become true. (well mine has)

I know, I know, for the first time players (who never played this on mobile) it will feel strange, yes, strange, all of it. (gfx, control, etc). But the good thing is that the controls are easy to get used to (ex: mouse is for lazy bones). 
Support for certain type of controllers might be lacking, but it compensates for the easy to get into multiplayer, where defeating other players will leave a nice taste in your mouth. 
Singleplayer part is quite good, considering it was made for mobile, it doesn't get boring (except for certain missions and situations), it provides enough action to feel like time has flown by. 


All in all if you want to play a flying game that is easy to get into and don't want to waste your time with endless tutorials or frustrating content, blockers etc....then this is the game for you. (as long as you keep in mind, this is mostly a game for the fans of the mobile version)

Yes, graphics are a bit bland, fx are not top notch for our pc riggs, but keep in mind, this is not War Thunder or WoP. 
This is a casual flying fighter game, for those of us that wish to fly a plane and don't bother with the rest.

I really enjoy the multiplayer side as it is action packed, there are lots of rooms available and you can choose exactly what type of game you want to play. The planes look great, there are quite a lot of them, and I've appreciated being able to customize the plane's color scheme (which is available in various templates to start with) - being able to add custom decals would have been something I would have appreciated as well.

Overall, if you want some solid MP action with fast kills, it's a good game to try!

review:
View my first playthrough [url=http://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLaFOFuH1JWgJxLEwazlfLLn_tiwtzk3pT] Here [/url]

This Arcade-style dogfighting game is a nice change from the horde of twitch-shooters currently on the market. It's one of those easy-to-learn-hard-to-master games that seems simple at first, but over time you'll learn there is depth to the combat. With close to 30 planes, all with varying stats and play-styles, you'll find something you like. The single player places you in one of three theatres of war across the globe during WWII. The difficulty ranges from piss-easy to OMFG-EJECT EJEC-(explosion). You'll fly sorties for the British and the Americans fighting against Germany and Japan, all while utilizing various frames: fighter, bomber, and special role planes. Each with there own unique weapons. Frames are unlocked by perfoming  campaing missions or playing multiplayer. The weapon and plane specifications could use an EXPLINATION, however. I'm not sure what some of these symbols mean, but I'm sure there is a wiki on it somewhere. Multi-player is fun and has several modes: capture the flag, defend the base, deathmatch, team deathmatch, last-man-standing, survival (horde, you and team versus NPCs) and even a free-flight mode for the achievment horses to mingle! In a market thourghly saturated with hyper-violent, grim and sexual content, this game is a breathe of fresh air. I would feel comfortable letting my kids play this game. 

Final verdict: this game is good, not great, but with patching it has the potential for excellence. View my livestream at twitch for my first sortie with this game
